docTitle.titlePart:
Why Simultaneous Sizing and Fluorescence is Necessary in
Order to Do Microbial Detection

front.div:
Many devices detect the size of particles, many detect fluorescence, and some even do
each sequentially. This whitepaper explains why none of these methods is sufficient and
why is it necessary that size and fluorescence be measured simultaneously, and for each
particle individually.
The best way to approach this question is to consider what would happen if the
simultaneous determination of auto florescence and sizing were not possible. First, let's
consider what information is gained solely by sizing particles, as is done every day by a
variety of commercially available particle detectors, many of which are mandated for use
in areas such as pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities. As is shown in Fig. 1, the size
ranges of several biological and inert particles overlap (such as is the case with dust and
bacteria), so knowing that one or more particles exist, for example, in the 5 micron range
is not determinative of if the particle is bacteria or dust. As a result, particle counters
cannot unambiguously measure microbial contamination.
Fig. 1 Graph of particle size ranges of relevant substances.
Next, let's consider the case where only fluorescence is measured. Properly used, some
types of fluorescence are very useful to determine whether a particle is biological or inert.
